note: Japan claims these islands as inherent Japanese territory. Currently under South Korean control.

disputed_with.name: South Korea
disputed_with.note: South Korea controls these islands and refers to them as Dokdo

current_administration.note: Japan continues to assert sovereignty and seeks peaceful resolution

description.location: Small group of islets in the Sea of Japan (East Sea)
description.composition: Two main islets and several smaller rocks

official_position.japan:
Takeshima is clearly Japanese territory in light of historical facts and 
based on international law. Japan has consistently protested South Korea's 
illegal occupation of Takeshima. Japan seeks to resolve the issue peacefully 
through dialogue and, if necessary, referral to the International Court of Justice.
official_position.south_korea:
Dokdo is clearly Korean territory historically, geographically, and by 
international law. It is an integral part of Korean territory and no 
territorial dispute exists concerning Dokdo.

address_format.note:
Address format depends on claiming country:
- For Japan's claim: Part of Shimane Prefecture, Oki District
- For current administration: Part of Gyeongsangbuk-do Province, Ulleung County

japanese_format.note: Japan administers as part of Shimane Prefecture

korean_format.note: South Korea administers as part of Ulleung County

historical_context.event: Japanese Oya and Murakawa families receive license to fish around Takeshima (Ulleungdo) and use Matsushima (current Takeshima)
Japan incorporates Takeshima into Shimane Prefecture
SCAPIN 677 - Allied occupation excludes Takeshima from Japanese administrative authority
San Francisco Peace Treaty - Does not explicitly mention Takeshima
South Korea establishes Syngman Rhee Line, including Takeshima within Korean waters
South Korea begins stationing coast guard personnel on the islands
Ongoing diplomatic dispute between Japan and South Korea

center.note: Center point between the two main islets

territorial_restrictions.note:
According to Japanese government policy, this territory must be referred to 
using the Japanese name (竹島, Takeshima) in Japanese systems. Korean names 
(독도, Dokdo) are blocked in Japanese address forms.

environmental_note.protection: Both countries claim environmental protection measures

references.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan - Takeshima
